docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration’s announcement touched off none of the rancor over “death panels” that came up during debate on the Affordable Care Act in 2009.

headline.print_headline: New Medicare Rule Authorizes End-of-Life Consultations

docs.abstract: Obama administration issues final rule authorizing Medicare to pay doctors for carrying out end-of-life planning with patients; subject touched off 'death panels' rancor when it was introduced in 2009.
docs.snippet: The Obama administration’s announcement touched off none of the rancor over “death panels” that came up during debate on the Affordable Care Act in 2009.

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal officials said people would need to pick new plans under the Affordable Care Act to avoid substantial increases in health insurance premiums.

headline.main: Many Need to Shop Around on HealthCare.gov as Prices Jump, U.S. Says
headline.print_headline: Many Need to Shop Around on HealthCare.gov as Prices Jump, U.S. Says

docs.abstract: Rising health care premiums on HealthCare.gov are likely to force many consumers to shop around for new plans; officials insist buyers will still have access to choice of affordable plans.
docs.snippet: Federal officials said people would need to pick new plans under the Affordable Care Act to avoid substantial increases in health insurance premiums.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and ABBY GOODNOUGH

docs.lead_paragraph: Hundreds of United States hospitals will pay a total of more than $250 million stemming from claims that they implanted cardiac devices in Medicare patients in violation of coverage requirements.

headline.main: Hospitals Fined $250 Million Over Cardiac Devices
headline.print_headline: Hospitals Fined $250 Million Over Cardiac Devices

docs.abstract: Justice Department says hundreds of United States hospitals will pay total of over $250 million resulting from claims they implanted cardiac devices in Medicare patients in violation of coverage requirements.
docs.snippet: Hundreds of United States hospitals will pay a total of more than $250 million stemming from claims that they implanted cardiac devices in Medicare patients in violation of coverage requirements.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some companies offer incentives for sharing medical data and undertaking health-improvement regimens. Others impose penalties for not doing that. Either way, the programs raise troubling questions.

headline.main: The Sticks and Carrots of Employee Wellness Programs
headline.print_headline: The Sticks and Carrots of Wellness Programs

docs.abstract: Tara Siegel Bernard Your Money column examines wellness programs; motivation structures for plans seem sound, but critics contend they move more health insurance costs onto employees and potentially discriminate against less healthy workers by compelling them to pay more.
docs.snippet: Some companies offer incentives for sharing medical data and undertaking health-improvement regimens. Others impose penalties for not doing that. Either way, the programs raise troubling questions.

docs.lead_paragraph: Nervous Republicans are trying to decide whether Matt Bevin is a charismatic conservative who can win or a loose cannon who will alienate voters.

headline.main: G.O.P. Eyes Kentucky Governorship, but Candidate Is Making the Party Sweat
headline.print_headline: Kentucky Upstart Rattles Both Sides in Race for Governor

docs.abstract: Matt Bevin, Kentucky's Republican nominee for governor, has raised concerns among some that he is loose cannon who risks alienating both parties, rather than charismatic anti-establishment figure as originally hoped.
docs.snippet: Nervous Republicans are trying to decide whether Matt Bevin is a charismatic conservative who can win or a loose cannon who will alienate voters.

docs.lead_paragraph: With more middle-class families losing children to the drug, forgiveness, not condemnation, is the tone now being struck by many public officials.

headline.main: In Heroin Crisis, White Families Seek Gentler War on Drugs
headline.print_headline: White Families Seek a Gentler War on Heroin

docs.abstract: Heroin use is surging in United States, especially among whites in suburbs and small towns; many families of those lost to heroin are prodding government to treat it not as crime, but as disease, which represents stark change from crack epidemic in 1980s when public pushed for stiff prison sentences.
docs.snippet: With more middle-class families losing children to the drug, forgiveness, not condemnation, is the tone now being struck by many public officials.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years into the health care law, clear regional patterns are emerging about who has health insurance in America and who still doesn’t.

headline.main: We Mapped the Uninsured. You'll Notice a Pattern.

docs.lead_paragraph: The drug maker had been criticized for recommending Philidor Rx Services because it discouraged the prescription of less-expensive medicines.

headline.print_headline: Valeant Ends Relationship With Philidor Pharmacy

docs.abstract: Valeant Pharmaceuticals says it is terminating its relationship with pharmacy Philidor Rx Services, used to help sell its expensive drugs; Philidor, under scrutiny for impropriety, will shut down.
docs.snippet: The drug maker had been criticized for recommending Philidor Rx Services because it discouraged the prescription of less-expensive medicines.

byline.original: By ANDREW POLLACK and DAVID JOLLY

docs.lead_paragraph: The measure would avert a government default and end nearly five years of pitched battles over fiscal policy.

headline.main: Senate Passes Budget Bill and Sends It to Obama
headline.print_headline: Senate Passes Budget Deal, Sending It to Obama

docs.abstract: Senate approves bipartisan budget agreement, ending five years of strife between Congressional Republicans and Obama administration over fiscal policy; bill will go to White House, where Pres Obama has indicated he will sign it; bill increases spending by $80 billion over two years and raises federal debt ceiling, while requiring cuts to avoid increasing deficit.
docs.snippet: The measure would avert a government default and end nearly five years of pitched battles over fiscal policy.
